bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, [June 16?, 1902]

div1.p: Reed is devastated to learn that their orchard is crawling with locusts. Reed hears that the President is highly complimentary of him. He will be coming home soon.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, [June 16?, 1902]
div1.opener:
Keep
up a
cheerful
heart-
our or->
chard &
lawn will
not be
destroyed.
Monday Evening,
My precious wifie:
div1.p:
I got your
darling letter written Satur-
day afternoon when I reached
my office, this morning, and I don't
know when I ever had any thing
to give me more distress than your
account of those dreadful locusts.
My first impulse was to go right
up, this afternoon, and try to as-
sist you in some way in keeping
our trees from destruction! but
as I thought over it, I concluded
that I had better go to the Agri-
cultural Dep't, & see if I could
find out any thing that would
be of assistance or comfort to
us- I went over, therefore, and had
a long talk with Mr Marlatt, the
expert on this subject, and put all
the facts before him about my
trees- He says that we need not
worry so much, as he can assure
us that not one of our older
trees will be killed by the locusts-
He says that while they will be
badly stung, that the only damage
will be the loss of last year's
growth- He doubts whether many
of our young trees will be killed --
perhaps here & there one or
two- What was of particular
interest to me, he showed
me a row of apple trees, about
the size of my larger trees, which
he has purposely cut off about
3 feet from the ground, remov-
ing the whole top, as an exper-
iment, each year for the last
three years, and which now look
perfectly beautiful- Pear trees
treated the same way are very
luxuriant- He says that if our
trees are stung so badly that they
would lose every branch (which
he has never known) we would
only need to severely prune them
this fall, & they would soon
regain their size- He told me
to assure you that your fears
were greatly exaggerated & that
we will not lose our orchard -- so
precious heart, I feel greatly en-
couraged- Mr Marlatt says that
we must not keep our trees
wrapped up too long in muslin
as when removed the sun might
scald the leaves badly- Leave
it on, however, until I come up-
I hope to come by Friday or Satur-
day & think that I will then come
for 15 days- What a glorious
rain we have been & are now
having- It is simply delightful-
Yesterday was intolerably hot
here- Save me some strawberries-
Borden tells me that Senator Warren
told him on Saturday that the President
had spoken in the highest terms to him con-
cerning my work in Cuba- Don't be discouraged
Bless my sweet babies hearts-
